newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Zambia's Kaunda to boycott November election.
newsitem.headline: Zambia's Kaunda to boycott November election.

text.p: Zambia's former president and now main opposition leader Kenneth Kaunda said on Wednesday his party would boycott general elections called for November 18 by President Frederick Chiluba.

Controversial constitutional changes passed this year by a parliament dominated by Chiluba supporters block Kaunda from running for president although his United National Independence Party, UNIP, is free to take part.
Zambia's Kaunda to boycott November election
Kaunda, president for three decades until Chiluba ousted him in Zambia's first free elections in 1991, told a news conference neither he nor his party would take part.
"After a thorough examination of the state of our nation and events leading up to the election, UNIP has decided deliberately and consciously that we will not participate in the elections," he said.

He urged Zambian voters to boycott the poll, which is not being held until three weeks after the five-year mandate of Chiluba's government expires, and said UNIP would stage protest rallies even if the police banned them.
Foreign aid donors have threatened to block fresh aid to Zambia unless Chiluba overturns what they say are unfair constitutional amendments that prevent Kaunda challenging him.
